It was founded on June 7, 1933 as the ''Ateneo de Cagayan'' by an American Jesuit missionary, [[James Hayes (archbishop)|Fr. James T.G. Hayes, S.J.]], who later became the first [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cagayan de Oro|Archbishop of Cagayan de Oro]]. In 1958, Ateneo de Cagayan became a university and was renamed to its present name, Xavier University, in honor of the Jesuit missionary, [[Francis Xavier|St. Francis Xavier]]. There were at least two attempts by the alumni of the then ''Ateneo de Cagayan'' to revert the name of the University to ''Ateneo de Cagayan''. The first attempt was in the mid 1990's and the second attempt was in 2007. These attempts were, however, not widely supported and in the case of the 2007 proposal, not endorsed by the Xavier University â Ateneo Alumni Association (XUâAAA). Until today, the debate still continues.{{cite journal|month=December| year=2008|journal= The Crusader|publisher= Xavier University - Ateneo de Cagayan|volume=35|issue=5|page=21}} The official student publication is ''[http://www.thecrusaderpublication.com/ The Crusader]''. Its supreme student government is the [http://www.xudyante.com Xavier University â Central Student Government]. ==History== ===Beginnings=== Xavier University was founded on June 7, 1933 as ''Ateneo de Cagayan'', with only 17 First-year high school students. It was founded by [[James Hayes (archbishop)|Fr. James T.G. Hayes, S.J.]], who became the first Bishop and Archbishop of Cagayan de Oro. It was firstly located at Burgos Street, where the former St. Augustine Parochial School was also located. Cagayan de Oro, then ''Cagayan de Misamis'', with a population of around 50,000, had the finest port in Mindanao and was a fast-growing town. Gradually, the school grew with the community and opened college courses in June 1938, and Grades 5 to 7 in June 1940 to accommodate requests from parents all over Mindanao and Visayas. ===World War II=== It was then moved to its present location in Corrales Avenue. It eventually grew into a college and offered courses in [[Liberal Arts]], [[Teacher education|Education]] and [[Commerce]]. The school closed down on December 9, 1941, with only 614 students. It subsequently became the headquarters of the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] in [[Mindanao]] on May 2, 1942. On September 9, 1944, [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]] planes swooped in and bombed most of Cagayan de Misamis into piles of rubble, even for the school itself. Fr. Edward J. Haggerty, S.J., then [[Rector]] and Military Vicar to the U.S. Armed Forces from [[Borneo]] to [[Okinawa]], wrote these words in his diary: {{cquote|In 15 minutes, the American liberator bombers destroyed our labor of 15 years...|cquote}} Fr. Haggerty was awarded the U.S. [[Bronze Star Medal|Bronze Star]] medal on February 21, 1947 for his services as a volunteer chaplain of the Visayas-Mindanao Force during the war years. He also became an adviser to [[Wendell Fertig|Fertig's]] Guerrilla Government. Fr. Haggerty and his successor, Fr. Andrew F. Cervini, S.J., worked to reconstruct the school, and in 1946, regular classes recommenced. This was only interrupted again after the eruption of [[Mount Hibok-Hibok|Mt. Hibok-Hibok]] on August 30, 1947, when the campus housed refugees from [[Camiguin]], and even sponsored a boxing bout in its gym to raise funds for the victims. ===University Status=== In a bid for university status, Fr. Francisco Z. Araneta, S.J., then rector, had vowed to St. Francis Xavier that if ever Ateneo de Cagayan is conferred as a university before its Commencement Exercises on March 22, 1958, he will rename the university after the saint. On that fateful day, an hour before the Commencement Exercises, then-Secretary of Education Manuel Lim, had sent a telegram stating that Ateneo de Cagayan has now been granted university status. On August 27, 1958, Ateneo de Cagayan was inaugurated as a university and had officially become "''Xavier University â Ateneo de Cagayan''". It became the first university in Mindanao, and the first Jesuit institution, among those existing in the Philippines, even first before its sister school [[Ateneo de Manila University|Ateneo de Manila]] to be given university status. After the inauguration, a banquet was held in honor of then-[[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Carlos P. Garcia]], who was conferred, the very same day, the honorary degree Doctor of Laws, the first honorary degree given by the university.{{cite web|url=http://www.xu.edu.ph/index.php/about-xu/xu-history|title=History of Xavier University - Ateneo de Cagayan|publisher=XU Webteam|accessdate=2009-12-30}} ===Xavier University today=== Today, X.U. has four campuses, a grade school in Macasandig (about 2,000 students); high school in Pueblo and grade school annex (nursery to grade 6, also about 2,000 students); Manresa Complex that houses the College of Agriculture laboratory classes, extension programs and [[SEARSOLIN]]; and the Main Campus in Corrales Avenue — where X.U. has about 11,000 college, professional schools and technology students being trained.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} ==Schools and Colleges== ===Professional Units=== ====Graduate School==== '''Academic Programs:''' '''''Arts and Sciences:''''' *Doctor of Philosophy in Sociology *Master of Arts in Sociology *Master of Arts in Economics *Master of Arts in English *Master in English Language and Literature *Master of Arts in Psychology *Master in Psychology *Master of Arts in History *Master in History '''''Public Administration:''''' *Doctor of Public Administration *Master in Public Administration '''''Engineering:''''' *Master of Engineering '''''Health-related:''''' *Master of Arts in Nursing ====College of Law==== [[File:XULaw.jpg|220px|right]] As a Jesuit professional school, the College of Law strives for professional competence, developing men and women trained in the theory and practice of law.{{cite web|url=http://www.xu.edu.ph/index.php/about-xu/xu-history|title=College of Law|publisher=XU Webteam|accessdate=2009-12-30}} The College aims to instill into the students a Christian outlook as to be worthy members of the legal profession and the community, particularly in the pursuit of truth and the promotion of justice. It also desires to foster a high ethical standard in the legal profession under a regime of liberty and democracy. Further, it aspires to train the students for leadership and seeks to develop a social conscience within the context of the mission of Xavier University in knowledge, value, and service to God, to the people, the community, and the country. '''Course offered:''' *Bachelor of Laws (Ll.B.) Likewise, a plaque was presented to its dean, Atty. Raul R. '''Four-Fold Functions''' *Instruction *Research *Extension *Production '''Course Offerings:''' *Bachelor of Science in Agribusiness *Bachelor of Science in Agricultural Engineering *Bachelor of Science in Agricultural Science major in: **Agricultural Economics **Animal Science **Crop Science *Bachelor of Science in Developmental Communication major in: **Developmental Journalism **Educational Communication *Bachelor of Science in Food Technology On February 27, 2009, the [[Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)|Commission on Higher Education (CHED)]] in its Memorandum Order No. 3, declared Xavier as a Center of Development (COD) in Agriculture for a period of three years. As PIA, Xavier will be among the priority partners of CHED in implementing development projects in agriculture. Xavier also qualifies for a half a million grant to fund scholarships, continuing agriculture education programs, instructional materials development and upgrading of facilities including research laboratories, among other priority projects supported by CHED.{{cite web|url=http://aggies.xu.edu.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=259&Itemid=1|title=Xavier University named as 'Provincial Institute for Agriculture'|publisher=College of Agriculture website, November 20, 2009|accessdate=2009-12-21}} In April 2010, the College of Agriculture was awarded Level II re-accreditation for a period of five years by the [[Philippine Accrediting Association of Schools, Colleges and Universities]].{{cite web|url=http://aggies.xu.edu.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=259&Itemid=1|title=XUCA gets 5 year PAASCU Re-accreditation|publisher=College of Agriculture website, May 30, 2010|accessdate=2010-06-30}} Recently, the college was awarded Level III accreditation by PAASCU, one year after its Level II re-accreditation.{{cite web|url=http://www.xu.edu.ph/index.php/component/content/article/1-latest-news/559-aggies-awarded-paascu-level-iii-accreditation|title=Aggies awarded PAASCU Level III accreditation|publisher=XU Website, May 25, 2011|accessdate=2011-06-07}} ====College of Arts and Sciences==== The College of Arts and Sciences offers most of the university's teaching core subjects of all colleges (e.g. Filipino, English). There are two semi-honor classes and one honors class throughout the four year levels in high school. A student may be retained to the semi-honors and honors class provided that he or she will maintain his or her grades no lower than 82%. His or her average must not be lower than 85%. If a student fails two units in the final quarter, he or she will be required to attend the summer classes and will be placed on academic probation the following school year.
